These studies are mostly concerned with species pollinated by several groups of Hymenoptera, such as the relationship between Catasetinae/Stanhopeinae and euglossine bees (Dressier, 1968; Williams and Dodson, 1972; Ackerman, 1983) and the pseudocopulatory mechanism in Ophrys (Borg-Karlson et al.. 1985, 1987; Borg-Karlson, 1987; Paulus and Gack, 1990), among others. Several observations have indicated that there is low fidelity and low specificity between plant species and flies in many orchid groups (see Christensen, 1994, for a review of this subject), and few have shown a more specific relationship between plants and their pollinators (e.g. Borba and Semir, 1998). In addition, we know of no study carried out with several fly-pollinated species using a multiple population approach. While specialization is claimed to be a common feature in the Orchidaceae (Tremblay, 1992), recent studies have suggested that this is an exception in angiosperms and, as a rule, generalized systems are more common (Oilerton, 1996; Waser et al., 1996; but see Johnson and Steiner, 2000). Waser et al. (1996) questioned specialization in orchids, and, even in systems considered highly specific, e.g. pseudocopulation in Ophrys species, spatial variation in pollinator assemblage has sometimes been observed (Paulus and Gack, 1990). As pointed out by Waser et al. (1996), one of the weaknesses of several studies claiming specificity is that they survey only one population per plant species. In the majority of the limited number of studies which have included multiple conspecific populations, spatial variation in pollinator identity has been observed in several plant •© 2001 Annals of Botany Coiggany groups (Herrera, 1988: Horvitz and Schemske, 1990; Kato et al., 1993; Waser et al., 1996; Dilley et al., 2000) and it may be widespread. With this in mind, we studied pollination in 12 populations of five Brazilian Pleurothallis species at nine localities. These species are rupicolous, occurring on rocky outcrops in areas of ‘campo rupestre’ vegetation in eastern Brazil. All five species are intercompatible and partially selfincompatible (Borba et al., 2001b), have synchronized flowering and are sympatric to a degree. Two pairs of species show moderate (P. ochreata Lindl. and P. teres Lindl.) to high (P. johannensis Barb. Rodr. and P. fabiobarrosii Borba and Semir) similarity in flower morphology and odour, whereas the fifth species, P. adamantinensis Brade, differs from the others in both traits (E. L. Borba et al., pers. obs.). Based on allozyme studies, Borba et al. (2001c) suggested that the similarities in these two pairs of species may be due to convergence in allopatric species with similar pollination mechanisms, and that divergence to different pollination mechanisms in closely related species (P, johannensis and P. teres) may have occurred. In this study we attempt to verify: (1) the above-mentioned hypothesis; (2) the occurrence of specificity and constancy of pollination both within populations and species; and (3) the pre-pollination mechanisms of reproductive isolation. MATERIALS AND METHODS Fieldwork was carried out in areas of campo rupestre vegetation in the southeastern (Minas Gerais state) and northeastern (Bahia state) regions of Brazil. This formation is characterized by open herbaceous vegetation on sandy, stony soils, mixed with herbs and shrubs growing on exposed islands of quartzite, sandstone, gneiss or ‘canga’ (iron ore) rocks (Giulietti and Pirani, 1988; Borba and Semir, 1998). All five Pleurothallis species studied grow on rocky outcrops in open areas. The climate of these campo rupestre areas is included in the ‘Cwb’ type of Koeppen’s classification (Kõeppen, 1948): mesothermic climate with mild summers, with an average temperature of 17-4—19'6 CC. There is a summer rainy season lasting 7-8 months and a dry winter season lasting 3-4 months. We observed floral visitor activity in 12 populations of the five species (three populations of P. johannensis and P. teres, and two populations of P. fabiobarrosii, P. adamantinensis, and P. ochreala; Table 1, Fig. 1). Distances between conspecific populations ranged from 13 to 587 km, and distances between species ranged from sympatric to 1167 km (Appendix). Observations were made from 0630 to 1800 h (from dawn to nightfall), and all available flowers were marked at the end of the day and examined at dawn the next day to assess the removal of pollinaria during the night. All insect visitors collected were sent to specialists for identification and are deposited in the Museu de História Natural of the Universidade Estadual de Campinas (ZUEC), Sao Paulo, Brazil. We measured fruit set in randomly chosen inflorescences in populations of P. johannensis, P. teres and P. ochreata but not in populations of P. fabiobarrosii and P. adamantinensis because these species were only starting to flower. Vouchers are deposited in the herbarium of the Universidade Estadual de Campinas (UEC; Table 1). Floral morphology and scent and nectar production Pleurothallis johannensis and P. fabiobarrosii (Figs. 2A, B and 3 A, B). Flowers of these two species are similar in shape, size, and odour, differing mainly in labellum traits and colours. The plants have 6-8 cm-long erect inflorescences bearing on average six to eight (P. johannensis) or three to seven (P. fabiobarrosii) distichous, pendulous and somewhat tubular flowers as the sepals and petals are erect (Table 2). The sepals are approx. 7 mm long, fleshy and boat-shaped, with the lateral sepals fused and with a slightly gibbous base; they are yellow to purple with dark purple lines (P. johannensis), or red with carmine lines (P. fabiobarrosii). Floral visitors Pleurothallis johannensis and P, fabiobarrosii. In all populations of both species, the only floral visitors were fly species belonging to the family Chloropidae, mainly females of the genera Tricimba and Hippelates (Table 3). There was no difference in the composition of species visiting these tw'o Pleurothallis species. We noticed activity of dipteran species (families Sarcophagidae and Milichii-dae) near the Pleurothallis individuals, but they never visited their flowers. The Milichiidae species were the same ones that pollinate Bulbophyllum ipanemense Hoehne and B. involutum Borba, Semir and F. Barros (Orchidaceae) in these places. Visits occurred from 1200 to 1800 h {P. johannensis) or from 1000 to 1700 h (P. fabiobarrosii), with a peak in frequency from 1300 to 1500 h. Visits were more frequent after rainfall on warm days or on the day after a cold rainy day. On subsequent days, the number of visits decreased until the next rainfall. Visits ceased completely when the interval between rainy days was more than 4 or 5 d. Pollinaria were never removed from any of the marked flowers overnight (from 1800 to 0630 h). In all populations, only females of Tricimba sp. removed and deposited pollinaria efficiently in flowers of P. johannensis and P. fabiobarrosii, in spite of not being the most frequent floral visitor (Table 3, Figs. 3A, B and 5A). We observed 61 visits to flowers of P. johannensis (27 in Carrancas, 24 in Nazareno, and 8 in Itutinga) and 86 visits to flowers of P. fabiobarrosii (20 in Grao Mogol and 66 in Joaquim Felicio) by females of this species. This small fly (approx. 2-2 mm long and 1-2 mm high) approaches the flower with an erratic flight, landing on the sepals or sometimes the leaves. The insect quickly visits several flowers in inflorescences of one individual and sometimes also of nearby individuals, partially entering the flower, examining it with its proboscis and touching the sepals with its ovipositor. This behaviour lasts up to 5 min. We observed oviposition by individuals of Tricimba sp. many times. Examining senescent flowers, we noted that many of them had eggs, presumably of Tricimba sp., but no larvae or pupae were found. When the insect enters the flower, it fits into the narrow passage formed by the erect sepals, petals, labellum and calii. The labellum is pushed down as the fly lands on it, returning to its original position after the insect passes a certain point. When the fly forces its way out backwards, it touches the rostellum with its scutellum and removes the pollinarium and the anther cap (Fig. 3A, B). Just after removal of the pollinarium, the anther cap falls off, and the insect may go away, but frequently stays in the same plant. We sometimes observed deposition of the pollinarium in the same flower from which it had been removed, or in flowers on the same individual (geitonogamy). Hippelates neoproboscideus (Chloropidae) was the most frequent floral visitor of P. johannensis and probably P. fabiobarrosii, making some hundreds of visits in all populations (Table 3, Fig. 5B). We also observed rare visits of H, carretal to flowers of P. johannensis. Individuals of these two species are smaller than individuals of Tricimba sp. (up to 1 -8 mm long and 0*8 mm high) and did not oviposit in the flowers. They occasionally removed the pollinarium from the flowers, but are apparently not effective pollinators. Besides the smaller body size, the scutellum is also less developed, making these insects incapable of removing the pollinarium from all but the smallest of flowers. Moreover, because of the small scutellum, the pollinarium frequently does not attach properly to the dorsal thorax, but instead attaches on the wing. In such cases, the pollinarium was generally removed from the insect’s body whilst cleaning. Individuals of H. neoproboscideus hardly ever retained the pollinarium, but they may occasionally pollinate flowers. Individuals of H. neoproboscideus made self- and geitonogamic pollinations more frequently than individuals of Tricimba sp. Wre even observed removal of the pollinarium in seven flowers of one inflorescence by an individual of H. neoproboscideus, resulting in self- or geitonogamic pollinations in five of these flowers (it removed the other two pollinaria from its body during cleaning). Only one of these flowers initiated a fruit, the remainder falling off after 7-10 d. Pleurothallis teres and P. ochreata. In all populations of P. teres and P. ochreata studied, flowers were visited by species of Megaselia (Díptera: Phoridae) and Apal lates, Hippelates and Tricimba (Díptera: Chloropidae; Table 3). Visits took place throughout the day, from 0700 to 1700 h, with the majority of visits by Phoridae species occurring in the first half of the morning and early afternoon. We observed a similar relationship between the frequency of visits to P. teres and P. ochreata and the occurrence of rainfall as described for P. johannensis and P. fabiobarrosii. Pollinaria were not removed from any of the marked flowers during the night (from 1800 to 0630 h). Females of Megaselia spp. efficiently removed the pollinarium of flowers in all populations (Figs 3D, F and 5C). The insect must enter the labellum base as its mouth parts are short, and it stays there feeding for some minutes. During this process, the fly touches the elongated rostellum, becoming trapped by the rostellar glue for up to 5 min. The insect forces itself backwards, removing the pollinarium with the anther cap and these become attached to the scutellum (Fig. 5C). The anther cap may remain on the dorsal thorax for several minutes, and can be there more than half an hour. The fly returns frequently to the same flower or to another flower of the same individual during this time. However, retention of the anther cap makes it difficult for the insect to reach the base of the labellum to feed on the nectar-like liquid, thus avoiding deposition of the pollinarium in the stigmatic cavity (Fig. 3F). The insect usually flies away with the pollinarium attached to its thorax, reducing the probability of self- or geitonogamic pollination (Fig. 3D). Occasionally, the anther cap falls off before the insect leaves the plant, and we observed geitonogamic pollinations. Females of Megaselia spp. did not lay eggs in the flowers or on any other part of P, teres or P. ochreata. We observed males of Megaselia spp. seeking females in the flowers and trying to copulate with them. Individuals of Tricimba sp., the main pollinator of P. johannensis and P. fabiobarrosii, were observed making rare visits to flowers of P. teres and P. ochreata. However, these flies cannot completely enter flowers of the latter two species, being bigger than Megaselia spp. (Fig. 5 A and C). Tricimba sp. have a longer proboscis and thus can reach the nectar-like liquid from the distal half of the labellum (Fig. 3C); consequently, they do not remove the pollinarium. Hippelates neoproboscideus (Fig. 5B), an occasional pollinator of P, johannensis and P, fabiobarrosii, was the most frequent visitor of P. teres and occasionally removed pollinaria from its flowers. However, this fly managed to remove the pollinarium from its body about 90 % of the time, by cleaning itself with its legs and wings, as described previously. Because it retained pollinaria in a few cases (Fig. 5B), it may be considered an occasional pollinator of P. teres: pollinarium deposition in the stigmatic cavity was observed on a few occasions. A similar pattern was observed for individuals of H. parvicalcar in relation to P. ochreata (Table 3). Rarely, an individual of Hippelates sp. visited flowers of P. teres with a pollinarium of P. adamantinensis attached to its thorax. This species is the main pollinator of P. adamantinensis, but due to its large body size no inter-specific pollination took place (Fig. 3E). Pleurothallis adamantinensis. During the observation period, flowers of P. adamantinensis were only visited by flies belonging to the families Chloropidae and Sarcophagidae. Only genera belonging to the family Chloropidae. namely Hippelates, Apallates and Trigonoma, removed pollinaria from flowers (Table 3). Pollinaria were not removed from anv of the marked flowers during the night (from 1800 to 0630 h). Individuals of Hippelates sp. were the most efficient pollinators. Flies land on a flower or inflorescence axis and go to the apex of the lateral sepals, where they enter the flower. A fly holds the sepal margins and starts licking the labellum, pushing it against the bottom of the cavity formed by the boat-shaped sepals. In this position the fly does not touch the column (Fig. 4A, B). When the insect tries to reach the nectar-like liquid deposited at the base of the labellum, in the deepest part of the cavity, it leaves the sepal margins and clings to the labellum (Fig. 4C). This allows the hinged labellum to return to its original position, pressing the fly against the column and causing it to be glued to the rostellum. The insect forces itself backwards, removing the pollinarium that has become attached to its scutellum (Fig. 4D). The anther cap falls off just after removal of the pollinarium, and the insect usually goes to another flower (Fig. 4E, F). A fly will occasionally stay in the same flower or go to another flower on the same plant, in which case self-pollination may occur. The most frequent floral visitors were small-sized individuals of Apallates sp. and Trigonoma sp. In spite of the high frequency of visits made by these two species (more than 300), removal of pollinaria was only observed five times by Trigonoma sp. and more rarely by Apallates sp. due to their small body size. They may thus only be considered occasional pollinators of P. adamantinensis. Some Sarcophagidae species that tried to visit flowers of P. adamantinensis could not enter the flowers due to their large body size. Fruit set A summary of the production of flowers and fruits in populations of P. johannensis, P. teres and P. ochre at a is presented in Table 2. In the two populations of P. teres, fruit set was similar (6-9 and 7*1 %). This was not the case for the other two species. At most, we observed six fruits per inflorescence. The number of inflorescences bearing fruits was variable among populations (21-5-68-9%). The highest numbers of fruits per inflorescence, fruit set, and inflorescences bearing fruits were found in the Grão Mogol population of P. ochreata, and the lowest numbers in the Nazareno population of P. johannensis. DISCUSSION With regard to specificity, we will pay special attention to three points in this system: (1) specificity in conspecific populations; (2) monophily/oligophily in all species; and (3) specificity among species. The high specificity found in conspecific populations of all five species, with all populations of each species sharing the same pollinators despite sometimes being hundreds of kilometres apart, was unexpected (see Appendix). Only a few studies on floral biology in the Orchidaceae have focused on more than one population per species, and examples of myophilous species are even more rare. There are no previous reports of the same single species or limited set of species pollinating different populations (e.g. Vogt, 1990), Myophily is considered one of the most promiscuous and generalized pollination syndromes in angiosperms (van dcr Fiji and Dodson, 1966; Faegri and van dcr Fiji, 1979; Proctor et a!., 1996), and even in systems considered highly specific, such as pseudocopulation in Ophrys species, conspecific populations using different pollinator species in different places have sometimes been observed (Paulus and Gack, 1990). Similar results, showing spatial variation in pollinator identity, have frequently been found in other plant groups (Herrera, 1988; Horvitz and Schemske, 1990; Kato et al., 1993; Waser et ah, 1996; Gomez and Zamora, 1999; Dilley et al., 2000), even though these multiple population studies are rare. Independent of the pollination system, pollinator specificity has recently been questioned, and generalized systems are considered the rule in angiosperms (Oilerton, 1996; Waser et al., 1996). Our results do not support this view- but instead strengthen that of Johnson and Steiner (2000), who believe specialized pollination systems are not as rare as has recently been postulated. In a previous study of myophilous Bulbophyllum species occurring in Brazilian campos rupestre vegetation, we found that these species attracted the same pollinator species in the field and glasshouse even though the two areas were hundreds of kilometres apart (Borba and Semir. 1998). In that study we suggested that specificity might occur in conspecific populations of these species, but our results were not conclusive. Monophily or oligophily (sensu Faegri and van der Fiji, 1979) is often mentioned in orchids pollinated by Hyme-noptera (Dodson, 1962; van der Fiji and Dodson, 1966; Dressier, 1968, 1981, 1993; Stoutamire, 1975; Paulus and Gack, 1990) but only occasionally in myophilous orchids (Dodson, 1962; van der Fiji and Dodson, 1966; Jones and Gray; 1976; Christensen, 1994; Borba and Semir. 1998). Conversely, it is much more common to find orchid species pollinated by several fly species or even systems considered as promiscuous, in which the pollinators are several species of Diptera associated with Hymenoptera (van der Fiji and Dodson, 1966; Ivri and Dafni, 1977; Ackerman and Mesler, 1979; Bernhardt and Burns-Balogh, 1986; Christensen, 1994; Pedersen. 1995; Banzinger. 1996; Tan and Nishida. 2000). It is important to note that the two species showing the highest specificity (i.e. monophily) do not produce nectar (P. johannensis and P. fabiobarrosit) and completely deceive the pollinator to the extent that it even lays eggs. Some authors have stressed that carrion and dung flowers (sapromyophily) are deceiving the female pollinators independently of nectar production (Dafni, 1984; Proctor et al., 1996), it being a partial deceit system. However, this point of view is controversial (van der Fiji and Dodson, 1966; Faegri and van der Fiji, 1979). We could expect that full deceit systems, as observed in P. johannensis and P. fabiobarrosii, should be advantageous because they are possibly more effective in the attraction of visitors. However, brood site deception could compromise pollinator reproduction and consequently reproduction of the plant. Conversely, the similarity in fruit set among these Pleurothallis species does not support either of the two hypotheses. Furthermore, both monophily and oligophily, as well as high and low visitor frequencies and pollinator constancy, have been observed in species presenting full or partial (i.e. carrion or dung flowers presenting nectar) brood site deception (Vogel, 1961; Meve and Liede, 1994). The most frequent visitor in all populations of all species was not the effective pollinator. These Pleurothallis species appear to select against the morphology (small scutellum) of these smaller visitors and also their tendency to remove pollinaria from their thorax. Additionally, their promiscuous behaviour favours hybridization. According to Proctor et al. (1996), the evolution of the pollinarium in orchids, in which the whole pollen load is removed in a single visit, makes it possible for the plant to rely on minority pollinators, which it can attract specifically and utilize with great effectiveness. Other systems like this, in which the most frequent visitor species is not the most efficient pollinator, have been observed in plant species with specialized pollination mechanisms (e.g. Horvitz and Schemske, 1990) and may be common in angiosperms. In this system, overlap of pollinators does not occur where sympatry exists. Specificity in this Pleurothallis group is probably due to specific chemical compounds. However, mechanical barriers provide important additional selectivity, as in the attraction of the pollinators of P. adamanti-nensis, P. johannensis and P. fabiobarrosii to the flowers of P. teres. This specificity is important in maintaining isolation because all five species are intercompatible (Borba et al., 2001a). Some similar systems have been described in other Orchidaceae as well as other plant groups (Vogel, 1961, 1990; Dodson, 1962; van der Fiji and Dodson, 1966; Dressier, 1968; Paulus and Gack, 1990; Dilley et al., 2000). A particularly similar case to this one is the study by Brantjes (1980) regarding sympatric Aristo-lochia (Aristolochiaceae) species pollinated by flies of Chloropidae and Phoridae. This study included the five species of Pleurothallis occurring in campo rupestre vegetation, characterized by their similarity in habit (nearly cylindrical leaves), inflorescence and floral morphology. However, it is possible that some of the fly species found, mainly in the Phoridae, may pollinate other Pleurothallis species occurring in neighbouring areas. Species of Phoridae (mainly Megaselia) and Chloropidae are often pollinators of several plant groups (Brantjes, 1980; Wolda and Sabrosky, 1986; Disney, 1994; Meve and Liede, 1994). In spite of this, pollination of members of the Orchidaceae by these flies is rarely mentioned and, with the exception of observations by Singer and Cocucci (1999) on pollination of Pleurothallis luteola Lindl. by Megaselia flies, has been reported only in genera not related to Pleurothallis (Christensen, 1994). Pollinators of Pleurothallis species generally belong to the dipteran families Sciaridae and Drosophilidae (Dodson. 1962; van der Fiji and Dodson, 1966; Chase, 1985); however, pollination studies in this orchid genus are still rare. We do not knowr of any other study that reports pollination by females of Tricimba species in any plant group, and we presume that the species we observed here is not anthophilous. Based on floral morphology and odour of these Pleurothallis species, we believe pollination by females of this Tricimba species is not likely to occur in any other Pleurothallis species occurring in campo rupestre vegetation or adjacent areas, at least not with the same mechanism observed in P. johannensis and P. fabiobarrosii. In our study of floral biology of Bulbophyllum species (Borba and Semir, 1998). we suggested a relationship between Neotropical Bulbophyllum species and Milichiidae fly species. Our results here support that hypothesis, since the Bulbophyllum species we studied are sympatric with these Pleurothallis species, and the pollinators of the species belonging to one genus never visited flowers of species belonging to the other (there is an overlap in body size among the pollinating species we observed in all these fly families). Borba et al. (2001c) suggested that the similarities in floral morphology and odour of flowers of the pairs of species, P. johannensis-P. fabiobarrosii and P. teres-P. ochreata, are due to convergence and do not represent an ancestrally inherited pattern (see Borba et al.. 2000, for a review of this group). Conversely, P. johannensis and P. teres—species with different floral morphologies-—are the most similar genetically among the five species studied. These conclusions were based on allozyme analyses and are supported by vegetative traits (E. L. Borba et al., pers. obs.) and by results on floral biology. Dodson (1962) proposed an evolutionary pathway for the genus Stanhopea (Orchidaceae), which he named 'leap-frog speciation’. According to his hypothesis, Stanhopea species shift from one pollinator group to another (in that case from small euglossine bees belonging to the genus Euglossa to the larger Eulaema and Eufrisea), with convergence among unrelated species and divergence among closely related ones. Some studies have pointed out that these convergences must be common in orchids (e.g. Johnson et al., 1998) as well as other plant groups (e.g. Sakai et al.. 1999). If this is indeed the case, then floral traits may be misleading indicators of phylogeny in some orchid groups due to similar pollination mechanisms (Paulus and Gack, 1990; Chase and Palmer, 1992; van den Berg et al., 2000). Pleurothallis ochreata is a species typical of the northeastern region of Brazil, mainly being found in Bahia state. The population we studied from Grão Mogol is the only one known in the state of Minas Gerais (see Fig. 1), and it differs in both chemical (Borba et al., 200\b) and leaf traits. However, all populations of this species are intercompatible (Borba et ah, 2001a), and allozyme data do not support its segregation as a new species (Borba et al.. 2001c). Our current findings strengthen that position. Although P. ochreata and P. teres occur in the same mountain chain in Minas Gerais (the Espinhaço Range), they have never been found in sympatric populations, but hybridization might be expected to occur if these species came into contact because they are interfertile (Borba et al., 2001a), attract the same pollinators and flower synchronously. In contrast to the apparent continuous distribution of P. johannensis and P. teres (see Fig. 1), these two species occur in rocky outcrops of different geological formations and are geographical!}' isolated. We suggest that occupation of these distinct areas has occurred by differentiation of these species. The pollination mechanism we observed in all species except P. adamant inensis is common in other Pleurothallis species (Chase. 1985; Singer and Cocucci, 1999) as well as some Bulbophyllum species (Ridley. 1890; van der Fiji and Dodson, 1966; Jones and Gray, 1976; Braga. 1977). Pleurothallis adamantinensis presents a slightly different mechanism, in which the weight of the insect is insufficient to push the labellum against the bottom of the cavity formed by the lateral sepals. In this mechanism the fly holds the sepal margins, pushing the labellum as it licks it. When the insect moves from the sepal margins to cling to the hinged labellum, the labellum returns to its original position pushing the fly against the column. This is made possible by the different morphology of P. adamantinensis, as its flowers are not laterally closed as they are in the other species (see Figs 3 and 4). Retention of the anther cap after removal of the pollinarium from flowers of P. teres and P. ochreata has been reported in other orchids (Catling and Catling, 1991), including P. luteola, a species also pollinated by Megaselia flies (Singer and Cocucci, 1999). We believe that such a mechanism is an adaptation to the pollinator’s habit of making long visits and visiting several flowers on the same plant, which would lead to a high frequency of self-pollination. Several different mechanisms to prevent self-pollination have been found in orchids pollinated by flies or other insects exhibiting such behaviour (van der Pijl and Dodson, 1966; Adams and Goss, 1976; Ackerman and Mesler, 1979; Dressier, 1981; Borba and Semir. 1999). Apparently this pre-pollination mechanism associated with genetic barriers (partial self-incompatibility and inbreeding depression; Borba et al,, 2001a) is responsible, at least in part, for maintaining high levels of genetic variability in these species (Borba et al., 2001c), Despite there being no differences in genetic variability among species which do or do not retain the anther cap (Borba et al., 2001c), such a mechanism avoids wasting pollen in pollinations that would rarely produce fruits (partial self-incompatibility) or that would produce fruits with only a few viable seeds (inbreeding depression; Borba et al., 2001a). Studies characterizing the volatile floral compounds of these species are essential for a better understanding of the relationships between Pleurothallis species and their pollinators, as well as for understanding the evolution of this orchid group and its convergence with Bulbophyllum species. Trabalho parcialmente desenvolvido sob orientação do Prof. Dr. George John Shepherd, Departamento de Botânica da UNICAMP, no Laboratório de Biossistemática do Departamento de Botânica da UNICAMP O sistema de reprodução é um dos fatores mais importantes na determinação da variabilidade genética em espécies vegetais (Hamrick & Godt, 1990). Orquídeas são predominantemente auto-compatíveis (Dressler, 1993), e barreiras a autogamia são principalmente pré-polinização (van der PijI & Dodson, 1966). Porém, auto-incompatibílídade tem sido observada algumas vezes na familia, normalmente em espécies polinizadas por agentes que possuem comportamento que propicia a auto-polinização. Da mesma forma, hibridização em Orchidaceae é principalmente prevenida por barreiras pré-polinização. Neste trabalho, nós objetivamos verificar a existência de barreiras genéticas à formação de progénie originada por endogamia em cinco espécies de Pleurothallis de campos rupestres, que apesar de serem polinizadas por moscas que exibem comportamento que favorece a auto-polinização (CAPÍTULO 4), suas populações apresentam elevada variabilidade genética (CAPÍTULO 3). Objetivamos também verificar a existência de correlação entre frutificação e variabilidade genética ou endogamia nas populações, a ocorrência de barreiras genéticas à hibridização entre estas espécies e existência de correlação entre similaridade genética e potencialidade de hibridização. Foram realizadas 2.741 polinizações experimentais em 301 indivíduos de 24 populações das cinco espécies de Pleurothallis (uma de P. fabiobarrosii, quatro de P. ochreata, sete de P. Johannensis, dez de P. teres e duas de P. adamantinensis). Foram realizados quatro diferentes tratamentos experimentais para cada espécie: auto-polinização, polinização cruzada intrapopulacional, polinização interpopulacional intraespecífica (exceto P. fabiobarrosii) e polinização interespecífica bidirecional com as demais espécies (exceto P. teres x P. fabiobarrosii). Foram realizadas análises de correlação entre variabilidade genética baseada em isozimas (heterozigosidade média observada, Ho) e frutificação em polinização cruzada intrapopulacional, e entre coeficiente de endogamia (Pis) e frutificação em polinização cruzada intrapopulacional. A matriz de identidade genética de Neí baseada em isozimas foi comparada à matriz de frutificação em polinizações interespecíficas utilizando o teste de Mantel Uma amostra de 200 sementes por fruto em 1.014 frutos (totalizando 202.800 sementes) foi observada em microscópio para uma estimativa de viabilidade, baseada na presença e morfologia do embrião. Foram feitas lâminas de flores e frutos para observação de morfologia de tubos polínicos e ocorrência de fertilização em microscópio de epifluorescência. A frutificação em autopolinização foi significativamente inferior à frutificação em polinização cruzada intraespecífica em todas as espécies. Três espécies apresentaram auto-incompatibilidade fraca ou parcial: P. johannensis, P. ochreata e P. teres, com frutificação média de 12 a 13% em auto-polinização e de 39 a 59% em polinização cruzada. Ambas P. adamantinensis e P. fabiobarrosii podem ser consideradas mais estritamente auto-incompatíveis, com frutificação média de 4 a 5% em auto-polinização e de 79 a 81% em polinização cruzada. Não foi observada nenhuma diferença significativa na frutificação entre cruzamentos intraespecíficos intra e interpopulacionais em nenhuma espécie, e nem entre diferentes espécies em um mesmo tratamento. Não foi observada nenhuma correlação entre frutificação e variabilidade genética ou endogamía em nenhuma espécie. Todas as espécies são intercompatíveis, e não foi encontrada nenhuma correlação entre similaridade genética e potencialidade de hibridização. Foi observada uma elevada depressão endogâmica em todas as populações, com usualmente menos do 30% de sementes viáveis por fruto, enquanto frutos formados por polinização cruzada intra e interespecífica possuem predominantemente acima de 80% de sementes viáveis. Poliembrionia foi observada na maioria dos tratamentos, com alguns frutos apresentando cerca de 1-2% das sementes com dois embriões. Tubos polínicos em flores que não desenvolveram frutos apresentaram morfologia similar ao encontrado normalmente em espécies com auto-incompatibilidade gametofítica, se tornando irregulares e cheios de calóse, interrompendo o crescimento próximos à base da coluna. Nós sugerimos que auto-incompatibilidade e depressão endogâmica sejam responsáveis, pelo menos em parte, pela manutenção dos elevados valores de variabilidade genética encontrados nas populações destas espécies (CAPÍTULO 3). Concluímos também que hibridização nestas espécies é evitada principalmente por mecanismos pré-polinização (CAPÍTULO 4), assim como observado para a maior parte das espécies de orquídeas (Dressler, 1993). SHEPHERD Departamento de Botânica, Instituto de Biologia, Universidade Estadual de Campinas, Caixa Postal 6109, Campinas, São Paulo, 13083-970, Brazil Received: 3 November 2000 Returned for revision: 12 February 2001 Accepted: 23 March 2001 Intra- and interspecific experimental pollinations were made to determine the mating systems and the interspecific crossing potential in individuals from 24 populations of five Pleuroihallis species, Pleurothallis johamiensis. P. ochreata and P. teres show weak or partial self-incompatibility while P. adamantinensis and P. fabiobarrosil are more strictly self-incompatible. We found no differences in fruit set between intra- and interpopulaiion intraspecific crosses, and there was no correlation between fruit set and genetic variability or inbreeding in these species. All species are interfertile and showed no correlation between genetic similarity and crossing potential. We scored fruits for seed viability and observed a strong inbreeding depression in all populations; however, there was no difference in seed viability among intrapopulation, interpopulation intraspecific and interspecific cross-pollinations. These species are pollinated by flies with a behavioural pattern that facilitates self-pollination. Self-incompatibility and inbreeding depression are apparently important in the maintenance of the unusually high levels of genetic variability found in these species. As generally observed in other orchid species, barriers to hybridization between these Pleurothallis species are at the level of pollination. © 2001 Annals of Botany Company Key words: Pleurothallis, Orchidaceae, mating system, self-incompatibility, inbreeding depression, fruit set, seed set, polyembryony, interspecific compatibility. INTRODUCTION Mating systems are one of the most important factors determining genetic variability in plant species (Hamrick et al., 1979; Hamrick, 1982, 1989; Hamrick and Godt, 1990). Orchids are typically self-compatible, and barriers to autogamy generally occur before pollination (Fiji and Dodson, 1966; Dressier, 1981, 1993; Borba and Semir, 1999). However, genetic barriers (i.e. self-incompatibility) have been found in some orchid species. Genetic barriers are usually associated with species pollinated by insects that often remain on the flowers and inflorescences for a long time (e.g. flies); this behaviour may promote geitonogamy (Christensen, 1992; Pedersen, 1995). Barriers to hybridization between orchid species are also generally mechanical (i.e. pre-pollination), and related species are potentially interfertile (Dodson, 1962; Fiji and Dodson. 1966; Dressier, 1968, 1981, 1993; Borba and Semir, 1998u, 1999; Borba et al., 1999). We have studied the floral biology (Borba and Semir, 2001) and genetic variability (Borba et al.. 2001b) in five rupicolous Brazilian Pleurothallis species occurring on rocky outcrops in areas of ‘campo rupestre’ vegetation from the east of Brazil. These species flower synchronously, and some of them are sympatric. Species with overlapping distributions do not share pollinator species (Borba et al., 2000; Borba and Semir, 2001). This paper describes the breeding systems of individuals from 24 natural populations of P. johannensis Barb. Rodr., P. teres Lindl., P. fabiobarrosil Borba and Semir, P. ochreata Lindl., and P. adamantinensis Lindl.—species which occur in Brazilian campo rupestre vegetation. Our objective was to investigate whether: (1) there are genetic mechanisms preventing selfing, thus contributing to the maintenance of the high levels of genetic variability previously reported; (2) there is any correlation between fruit set following intrapopulation cross-pollination and genetic variability or inbreeding in the populations; (3) there are genetic barriers preventing hybridization; and (4) there is a correlation between genetic similarity and crossing potential among different species. Great care was taken to collect individuals from different clones, since these species can reproduce vegetatively. We used a total of 301 individuals of the five species. The individuals were maintained in a glasshouse at Universidade Estadual de Campinas, São Paulo state, Brazil (22°49'S, 47’06'W) for at least 6 months before beginning experiments. The climate experienced by wild populations of these species is similar to that of Campinas, Cwb in Koeppen’s (1948) classification. Vouchers are deposited in the herbarium of the Universidade Estadual de Campinas (UEC; Table 1). Seven (six for P. teres and P. fabiobarrosii) experimental hand-pollination treatments were carried out for each species as the pollen receptor: self-pollination; intraspecific intrapopulation cross-pollination; intraspecific interpopulation cross-pollination; and interspecific cross-pollination with each of the other four species. Interspecific crosses were not carried out between P, teres and P. fabiobarrosii due to the lack of sufficient flowers in the latter species. Only recently opened flowers were used. The order in which the treatments were applied in each inflorescence was random, and we did not perform more than six pollinations in a single inflorescence (the highest number of fruits in a single inflorescence in natural populations). The number of crosses varied among treatments and species, depending on the availability of flowers. Fruit initiation and development was monitored until fruits were mature (3-5 months depending on the species). We tested for differences in mean fruit set among the three intraspecific treatments within each species (self-pollination, intrapopulation and interpopulation crosspollination). and the same intraspecific treatment among different species. Data were arcsin transformed, and oneway ANOVA was performed with further Tukey multiple comparisons (Zar, 1999). Besides hand-pollination experiments, more than 50 unpollinated, non-emasculated flowers per population were monitored for the occurrence of apomixy and spontaneous self-pollination. We carried out a correlation analysis between genetic variability and fruit set in intrapopulation cross-pollinations, and between F1S (inbreeding coefficient) and fruit set in intrapopulation cross-pollinations in P. johannensis, P. teres, and P. ochreata, and for all populations of all five species pooled. Populations of P. adamantinensis and P. fabiobarrosii were not analysed separately as we only had data for one population of each. We used observed mean heterozygosity (Hf from allozyme data as a measure of genetic variability [data from Borba el al., (2001 b) in which the same individuals of these populations were used]. The inbreeding coefficient, which is a measure of the reduction in heterozygosity due to non-random mating within a population (Wright. 1978), was calculated as H„, where is the expected mean heterozygosity (data from Borba et al,, 2001b). All data were arcsin transformed before calculating the correlation coefficient; its significance was tested using table B.17 in Zar (1999). Bidirectional interspecific crosses between each pair of species were pooled to construct a matrix that was compared to a matrix of genetic similarity of these species (from Borba et al., 20016) using the Mantel test in PCOrd 4-10 (McCune and Mefford, 1999), Data were randomized with a Monte Carlo test. The estimated fruit set following cross-pollination in each species was calculated by pooling results for intra- and interpopulation crosses. We carried out a preliminary seed viability test, placing fresh seeds in a 1 % solution of 2,3,5-tri phenyl tetrazo lium chloride. All well-developed embryos stained red. indicating viable seeds; none of the rudimentary embryos were stained. Given these resuts, seeds from mature fruits were removed after the start of dehiscence and fixed in 50 % FA A. A sample of 200 seeds per fruit was scored for viability on a morphological basis only: seeds with well-developed embryos were considered viable, and seeds with no embryo or a rudimentary embryo were considered inviable. Mature fruits, aborted fruits, and flowers that did not begin fruit development were fixed in 50% FAA. These were softened in 8n NaOH at 60 °C for 60 min (fruits) or 30 min (flowers), washed in distilled water and then stained with aniline blue, squashed and observed by epifluorescence microscopy (modified from Martin, 1959) to examine pollen tube growth and ovule/seed morphology. RESULTS Fruit set Intraspecific pollinations. Fruits were not produced from spontaneous selfing or apomixy in any individual of any of the five species studied; thus pollinator visits are essential for fruit formation. We carried out a total of 2741 experimental crossings, with 1907 intraspecific and 834 interspecific pollinations. Flowers that did not begin fruit development withered and fell about 7—10 d after pollination. Fruits ripened after about 3 (P. johannensis and P. adamantinensis), 4 (P. ochreata and P. teres), or 5 (P. fabiobarrosil) months. A few fruits did not ripen, and aborted during development. Fruit set following experimental pollinations is summarized in Table 2. Fruit set ranged from 0 to 38*5 % per population and from 4*2 to 12*6% per species following self-pollination, from 21*1 to 80-8 % per population and 39-4 to 80*8 % per species following intrapopulation cross-pollination and from 33-3 to 82*7 % per population and 44-43 to 77-8 % per species after interpopulation intraspecific cross-pollination (Table 2). Considerable variation was observed among different populations of the same species. Populations with the highest fruit set following self-pollination did not necessarily have the highest fruit set following intraspecific cross-pollination. Fruit set was higher following intraspecific cross-pollination (both intra- and interpopulation crosses) than following self-pollination in all populations: it was 3-2 to 5*3 times higher in P. johannensis, P. teres and P. ochreata, and 14-8 to 19-2 times higher in 3 P. adamantinensis and P. fabiobarrosil. These values are all statistically significant (all values of P <0-01, except intrapopulation crosses for P, ochreata with P= 0*021; Table 2). Significant differences between intra- and interpopulation intraspecific cross-pollination did not occur in any of the species (all values of P > 0-99). The three intraspecific treatments did not differ significantly among different species (all values of P > 0*38). There were no significant correlations between genetic variability and fruit set in intrapopulation cross-pollinations in P. johannensis (r = 0.174, d.f. = 5, P > 0*05), P, teres (r = 0-443, d.f. = 4, P > 0*05), and P. ochreata (r = -0-738, d.f. = 2, P > 0-05), or in pooled populations of all five species (r — 0-002, d.f. = 17, P > 0-05; Fig. 1A). Nor were correlations between the inbreeding coefficient and fruit set in intrapopulation cross-pollinations in P. johannensis (r ~ 0-056, d.f. = 5, P > 0*05), P. teres (r = 0-588, d.f. = 4, P > 0-05), P. ochreata (r = -0-037, d.f. = 2, P > 0-05) or pooled populations of all five species (r = 0-014, d.f. = 17, P > 0-05; Fig, IB) significant. Interspecific pollinations. Fruit set following interspecific pollination was variable among different pairs of species and different populations of a single species, as noted for intraspecific crosses (Table 2), In all species, fruit set following interspecific crosses was always higher than that following self-pollination and was usually lower than that following intraspecific cross-pollinations, except in P. adamantinensis x P. johannensis, P. fabiobarrosii x P. adamantinensis, and in the majority of the crosses in which P. ochreata was the pollen receptor. The difference in fruit set between reciprocal crosses was high in five of the nine pairs of species crossed; these crosses always involved P. adamantinensis or P. ochreata. However, some of the lowest differences were found in reciprocal crosses between these two species (Table 2). A matrix of the pooled bidirectional interspecific crosses is presented in Table 3, and a matrix of genetic similarity based on allozyme data is given in Table 4 (from Borba et al., 20016). The Mantel test shows no significant correlation between genetic similarity and fruit set in interspecific crosses in these species (P = 0*261). Seed viability We scored 1014 fruits (689 from intraspecific crosses and 325 from interspecific crosses) for seed viability, with a total of 202 800 seeds. Fruits from intra- and interpopulation intraspecific cross-pollinations had a high percentage of viable seeds—over 80 % on average (Fig. 2A). There was little difference between these two treatments or among species. The percentage of viable seeds in fruits produced as a result of self-pollination was much lower (usually less than 30 %) than that observed following intraspecific crosspollinations; variation among fruits was also greater. The majority of seeds in self-pollinated fruits had rudimentary or partially developed embryos or no embryo at all (Fig. 3A). Pollen tubes observed in fruits with a high percentage of viable seeds were normal during the extension process (Fig. 3E). Pollen tubes persisted and could be stained so that indicators of fertilization were observable even after fruit ripening. Even fruits with a high percentage of seeds lacking embryos showed normal pollen tube growth to the placenta, at which point many of the tubes became irregular, filled with callose and formed a tangled mass around the ovules (Fig. 3F). A large number of unfertilized ovules and aborted seeds were visible. The greater the proportion of inviable seeds, the greater the proportion of anomalous pollen tubes, w'hich were more frequent following self-pollination. Pollen tubes in aborted fruits showed the same morphology as abnormal tubes in fruits with low-seed viability. DISCUSSION Intraspecific pollinations Classic self-incompatibility and self-compatibility are extremes of a continuum between which there is often no clear difference. As relatively few species fit these extremes exactly (Schemske and Lande. 1985), many authors have utilized different indices, generally comparing seed set between selfing and outcrossing, to determine whether a particular species is self-compatible or self-incompatible (Bawa, 1974, 1979; Zapata and Arroyo, 1978; Sobrevilla and Arroyo, 1982; Jaimes and Ramirez, 1999). The distinction between the two conditions is, however, arbitrary, and various authors have used different values. Some populations or species in this study, namely P. johannensis, P. teres and P. ochreata, could be considered to be self-incompatible or self-compatible depending on which criterion is employed. However, all these species showed pollen tube reactions similar to those observed in species with homomorphic gametophytic self-incompatibility (de Nettancourt. 1977; Dafni and Calder, 1987; Murfett et al.. 1996; Richards, 1997) and were homogeneous in the timing of the reaction in the stylar canal. These characteristics lead us to suggest the occurrence of weak or partial self-incompatibility in these three species. Conversely, P. adamantinensis and P. fabiobarrosii can be dearly considered self-incompatible. Recently, considerable discussion has taken place over the occurrence of inbreeding depression or late-acting selfincompatibility, especially in cases in which post-zygotic rejection occurs. The high number of seeds with no embryo or with aborted embryos in these Pleurothallis species may be due to inbreeding depression. This suggestion is based on the great variation in the number of viable seeds in selfpollinated fruits, together with differences in the size of aborted embryos, indicating differences in the timing of embryo death. Embryo abortion due to late-acting selfincompatibility is likely to occur at the same time, thus aborted embryos should be uniform in size. In contrast, inbreeding depression usually causes abortion at several stages, as well as a greater variation in seed set (Seavey and Bawa, 1986; Barrett, 1988; Gibbs et al., 1999; Lewis and Gibbs, 1999; Sage et al., ¡999; but see Mulcahy and Mulcahy, 1983). The presence of abnormal pollen tubes in the ovaries of aborted fruits or in fruits containing a high percentage of aborted seeds is more difficult to explain. Differences in pollen tube morphology between successful crosses and incompatible crosses in species exhibiting late-acting selfincompatibility, with rejection after micropylar penetration or post-zygotic rejection, are not common (James and Knox, 1993; Humeau et al., 1999; Lipow and Wyatt, 1999; Sage et al., 1999), and such differences would not be expected with inbreeding depression either. There may be a third mechanism of rejection in the ovary in these Pleurothallis species. Some authors have employed the expression ‘pistillate sorting’ to explain instances in which inbreeding depression occurs in association with selfincompatibility system(s), making a conclusive analysis difficult (Berlin et al., 1989; Gibbs and Sassaki, 1998). Diallelic crosses in progeny arrays are necessary for a more precise evaluation of the mechanisms involved in fruit failure and embryo abortion of these Pleurothallis species as well as in other orchid species presenting complex selfrejection mechanisms (Borba et al., 1999), but they are unlikely to be carried out due to the long period required for maturation (about 5-8 years). The level of inbreeding depression observed in all five Pleurothallis species is usually found in exclusively alloga-mous populations, being low as a rule in partially inbreeding populations, indicating that these Pleurothallis species may be mainly outcrossing in natural populations (Stebbins, 8 1974; Lande and Schemske, 1985: Schemske and Lande. 1985; Charlesworih and Charlesworth, 1987; Wiens et al., 1987; Husband and Schemske. 1996; Byers and Waller, 1999; but see Charlesworih and Charlesworih, 1990, and Charlesworih et al., 1990). Similar inbreeding depression at early stages of development (embryo abortion) has been reported for several orchid species (Lock and Profits, 1975; Stort and Martins, 1980; Catling, 1982; Stort and Galdino, 1984: Matias et al., 1996), and it may be widespread in the family. Besides being highly expressed during zygote formation and embryo development, inbreeding depression in angiosperms continues to be expressed in subsequent life stages of the plant, mainly growth and reproduction (Seavey and Bawa, 1986; Husband and Schemske, 1996; Culley ei al., 1999; Daehler, 1999; Kittelson and Maron, 2000). It is likely that only a few reproductive individuals are ever produced by self-pollination in these Pleurothallis species under natural conditions. Self-incompatibility, inbreeding depression and genetic variability The absence of any correlation between heterozygosity (Ha) or the inbreeding coefficient (f)3) and fruit set indicates that the relatively low fruit set in some populations is not due to crosses beween close relatives, as might be expected (Lipow and Wyatt, 1999). The similarities in fruit set and seed viability between intra- and interpopulation crosses support this conclusion. It is possible that these crosses show similar levels of fruit set for different reasons, with fruit sei being low in intrapopulation crosses due to crosses between relatives and in interpopulation crosses due to population differentiation. This explanation seems unlikely because of the high genetic similarities among these populations (Borba et al., 2001b). Variation in self-fertility among populations was relatively high in some species, especially in P. teres, and similar results have been found in other plant species (e. g. Lipow et al., 1999). Mating systems have been postulated to be one of the most important factors determining the genetic variability in plant species (Hamrick et al., 1979; Hamrick. 1982; Hamrick and Godt, 1990; Maki et al., 1999; Wong and Sun, 1999; Evans et aL, 2000). We believe that both partial self-incompatibility and inbreeding depression are responsible for the maintenance of the high genetic variability found in these Pleurothallis species (Borba et al., 2001b)— levels that are much higher than previously reported for other Orchidaceae (Scacchi and De Angelis, 1989; Schlegel st aL, 1989; Scacchi et aL, 1990; Corrias et aL, 1991; Klier et aL, 1991; Case, 1994; Wong and Sun, 1999). Orchids are usually considered self-compatible, with autogamy prevented mainly by herkogamy and pollinator behaviour (Lenz and Wimber, 1959; Fiji and Dodson, 1966; Dressier, 1981, 1993; Gill. 1989; Paulus and Gack, 1990; Nilsson, 1992) or less frequently by several pre-pollination mechanisms (Fiji and Dodson, 1966; Adams and Goss, 1976; Stoutamire. 1978; Ackerman and MesleT. 1979; Catling and Catling. 199M; Borba and Semir. 19986, 1999; Singer and Cocucci, 1999). However, exceptions have been found in some orchid groups, in which genetic barriers are responsible for low inbreeding (Stoutamire, 1975; Agnew, 1986; Johansen, 1990; Christensen. 1992; Dressier. 1993; Pedersen. 1995). These genetic and mechanical barriers are mainly associated with plants pollinated by insects that often remain on the flowers and inflorescences for a long time, promoting geitonogamy, as in these Pleurothallis species (Borba and Semir, 2001) and other myophilous species (Christensen. 1992; Pedersen, 1995; Borba and Semir, 19986, 1999; Singerand Cocucci, 1999). Unfortunately, we know of no other study reporting genetic variability in other self-incompatible members of the Orchidaceae, thus we cannot make comparisons among different strategies. Polyembryony Polyembryony has been reported in the Orchidaceae and is almost always associated with apomixy. the embryo being derived from the inner integument (Swamy, 1949; Lenz and Wimber. 1959; Catling, 1982. 1987: Catling and Catling, 19916). In all these cases, a higher percentage of multipleembryo seeds was reported (28-95 %) than was found for the Pleurothallis species in this study. Interspecific crosses usually lead to higher rates of apomictic embryo formation (O’Neill. 1997); however, we did not find any clear difference in the percentage of polyembryo seeds between intra- and interspecific crosses. Pintaúdi et al. (1990) reported the presence of a few rare two-embryo seeds in non-apomictic fruits of Xylobium squalens Lindl. (Orchidaceae). In that case, the second embryo originated from a division of the zygote. These characteristics, in addition to the fertilizations we observed, lead us to suppose that the extra-numerary embryos found in Pleurothallis may have a similar origin to those of Xylobium, and are unlikely to be the result of apomixy. Interspecific crossing potential Some studies have shown a positive correlation between genetic similarity or phylogeny and interspecific crossing potential (Sanford. 1964, 1967; Johansen, 1990; Scacchi et aL. 1990; Borba et aL, 1999), failure in crosses being caused by evolutionary divergence between species (Hogen-boom, 1975). However, we found no correlation between these variables in our study. We also found no correlation between genetic reproductive isolation and sympatry, which has been reported for some species (Coyne. 1992). The Pleurothallis species studied here fit the general model proposed for Orchidaceae in which related species are usually potentially interfertile and reproductive isolation is mainly assured by pre-pollination barriers (Lenz and Wimber, 1959; Dodson, 1962; Fiji and Dodson, 1966; Dressier, 1968, 1981. 1993; Steiner et aL. 1994; Borba and Semir. 1998u, h. 1999; Silva et aL. 1999). The Pleurothallis species that occur sympatrically attract different groups of pollinators (Borba and Semir. 2001), and mechanical barriers prevent hybridization in the few cases in wffiich the pollinator of one species visits another. Although P. ochreata and P. teres occur in the same mountain formation in Minas Gerais (the Espinhaço Range), they have never been found in sympatric populations. However, hybridization might be expected to occur if these species come into contact as they are interfertile, attract the same pollinators, and flower synchronously (Borba and Semir, 2001). Interpopulation crossing potential in P. ochreata The Grão Mogol population of P. ochreata is the only one known in the state of Minas Gerais—-the species occurs almost exclusively in the northeastern region of Brazil, mainly Bahia state (see Fig, 1 of Borba and Semir, 2001), This population shows some differentiation in chemical (Borba et al, 200Iff) and leaf traits, but allozyme data do not support its segregation as a new' species (Borba et al.. 200lb). This view’ is strengthened by data on floral biology (Borba and Semir, 2001), together with these results showing intercompatibility among all the populations of this species. CAPÍTULO 6 Floral and vegetative morphometry in five Pleurothallls (Orchidaceae) species: correlation with taxonomy, phylogeny, genetic variability and pollination systems. Artigo submetido para publicação no Annals of Botany em abril de 2001. Trabalho parcialmente desenvolvido sob orientação do Prof. Dr. George John Shepherd, Departamento de Botânica da UNICAMP, e com a colaboração do Dr. Cássio van den Berg, Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew, no Jodrell Laboratory, Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew. Delimitação de grupos e suas relações filogenéticas em Orchidaceae têm sido predominantemente determinadas através da utilização de caracteres florais. Porém, alguns biologistas florais têm chamado a atenção para a ocorrência de eventos de convergência em caracteres florais de orquídeas devido a mecanismos de polinização similares (van der Pijl & Dodson, 1966), acarretando consequentemente na elaboração de sistemas de classificação artificiais, Alguns destes casos de convergência têm sido confirmados recentemente através de estudos filogenétícos utlitizando dados macro molécula res (van den Berg et al., 2000). A ocorrência destes eventos de convergênia devido a sistema de polinização especializados, geralmente referidos como síndromes de polinização, tem sido motivo de intenso debate entre alguns autores (Herrera, 1996; Ollerton, 1996; Waser et al., 1996; Johnson & Steiner, 2000), e poucos trabalhos têm demonstrado a sua ocorrência de uma forma mais objetiva, por exemplo através da utilização de métodos morfométricos multivariados (Sakai et al., 1999). Foram encontradas inesperadas elevada variabilidade genética nas populações e baixa diferenciação genética entre populações conspecíficas em cinco espécies de Pleurothallis polinizadas por Díptera (CAPÍTULO 3). Estas espécies são polinizadas por três grupos de moscas: P. teres e P. ochreata, polinizadas por Megaselia spp. (Phoridae); P. johannensis e P. fabiobarrosii, polinizadas por Tricimba sp. (Chloropidae); P. adamantinensis, polinizada por Hippelates sp. (Chloropidae), ocorrendo uma aparente associação entre morfologia floral e grupos de polinizadores (CAPÍTULO 4). Baseado em estudos de isozimas, foi sugerido que a similaridade floral nas espécies com mesmos polinizadores seria devido a convergência, e que características florais não seriam bons indicadores de filogenia neste grupo. Neste trabalho, nós objetivamos confirmar a delimitação destas espécies de Pleurothallis, revisada recentemente (CAPÍTULO 1), verificar a hipótese de correlação entre morfologia floral e grupos de polinizadores (CAPÍTULO 4), determinar as relações filogenéticas entre as espécies e então testar as hipóteses de convergência e radiação em caracteres florais (CAPÍTULO 3), e verificar a existência de correlação entre variabilidade genética e variabilidade morfológica e na maneira como estas encontram-se distribuídas entre as populações conspecíficas. Para isto, nós realizamos uma análise morfométrica de caracteres vegetativos e florais em 21 populações de cinco espécies de Pleurothallis de campos rupestres (duas de P. fabiobarrosii, quatro de R ochreata, sete de PJohannensis, seis de P. teres e duas de P, adamantinensis) provenientes de 16 localidades dos estados de Minas Gerais, Bahia e Pernambuco. Foram medidos 35 caracteres morfológicos contínuos, sendo 26 florais e 9 vegetativos. Foi realizada uma Análise de Componentes Principais (PCA) para todos os indivíduos utilizando todos os caracteres. Foram feitas análises de agrupamento para as populações utilizando a Distância Generalizada de Mahalanobis e UPGMA como algoritmo de agrupamento, utilizando todos os caracteres e com caracteres florais e vegetativos separadamente. Foi utilizada uma análise de MRPP (Multi-Response Permutation Procedure) para calcular a dispersão média dos indivíduos dentro de grupos (delta) para as populações (utilizada como uma medida de variabilidade morfológica) e uma medida de sobreposição entre grupos (A) para as populações conspecíficas (utilizada como uma medida de diferenciação entre populações). Foram então realizadas análises de correlação entre valores de delta e variabilidade genética (Ho; heterozigosidade média observada), e entre valores de A e diferenciação genética entre populações (Fst). Correlações de distância de Mahalanobis e distância genética de Nei, e distância de Mahalanobis e distância geográfica entre as populações de PJohannensis e P. teres foram feitas utilizando o teste de Mantel. Também foi realizada uma análise filogenética das cinco espécies (oito populações) e mais cinco espécies de diferentes linhagens dentro de Pleurothallidinae utilizando sequências de ITS1 e ITS2 de DNA nuclear ribossomal, utilizando parsimonia e Octomeria gracilis como grupo externo. Os resultados da análise de ordenação (PCA) e de agrupamento concordam com a delimitação das espécies conforme proposta por estudos taxonómicos (CAPÍTULO 1) e também confirmada por estudos de isozimas (CAPÍTULO 3). Os três grupos formados nos dois primeiros eixos do PCA são coincidentes com os três grupos de polinizadores das cinco espécies (CAPÍTULO 4). Mesmo com a elevada similaridade floral de R johannensis e R fabiobarrosii mencionada anteriormente (CAPÍTULOS 1 e 4), a análise de agrupamento mostra que estas espécies podem ser distinguidas com base exclusivamente em caracteres florais. Resultados semelhantes foram encontrados para R teres e R ochreata. As relações interespecíficas observadas no estudo de isozimas (CAPÍTULO 3) são similares às relações encontradas na análise de agrupamento utilizando apenas caracteres vegetativos, mas não concordam com as relações observadas quando se utilizam apenas variáveis florais. Estes resultados sustentam a hipótese de que as similaridades em caracteres floráis nos pares de especies R teres-P. ochreata e P.johannensis-P. fabiobarrosii sejam resultado de eventos de convergencia em espécies com mecanismos de polinização similares, assim como tem sido observado em outras Orchidaceae (Johnson et al., 1998; van den Berg et a!., 2000). Desta forma, caracteres florais podem não ser bons indicadores de relações filogenéticas neste grupo, conclusão que tem sido extendida para outros grupos de orquídeas (Chase & Palmer, 1992). Os resultados da análise filogenética sustentam parcialmente esta hipótese, porém a diferenciação entre as espécies nas sequências de ITS1 e ITS2 é muita reduzida para uma análise conclusiva. Não foi observada qualquer correlação entre variabilidade morfológica e variabilidade genética nas populações, assim como na maneira que esta varialidade encontra-se distribuída nas populações conspecíficas, resultados frequentemente encontrados em diversos grupos de plantas, assim como de animais. Baseado em diferenças morfológicas de caracteres vegetativos encontradas neste trabalho, diferenças químicas (CAPÍTULO 2) e localização geográfica, nós descrevemos uma nova subespécie, Pleurothallis ochreata subsp. cylindrífolia. A categoria subespecífica ao invés de específica é reforçada pela ausência de diferenciação em caracteres florais, pela similaridade genética (CAPÍTULO 3) e pelos resultados de biologia reprodutiva das populações de P, ochreata, tais como atração de mesmos polinizadores e intercompatibilidade (CAPÍTULOS 4 e 5).
