Universitária s/n, Feira de Santana-BA, 44031-060, Brazil. running title: morphometry of Pleurothallis (Orchidaceae) species We carried out morphometric analyses of vegetative and floral characters in 21 populations of five Pleurothallis (Orchidaceae) species occurring in Brazilian “campo rupestre” vegetation. We also carried out a phylogenetic analysis of this species group using nuclear ribosomal ITS1 and ITS2 DNA sequences, The results of the ordination and cluster analyses are in agreement with the species delimitation proposed from taxonomic and allozyme studies. The groups formed in ordination analysis are coincident with the pollinator groups found in a previous pollination study. The relationships among the species in the cluster analysis using only vegetative characters is similar to that of a previous allozyme study. Conversely, the relationships suggested by cluster analysis using only floral characters are quite different. These results support a hypothesis that these floral similarities are due to convergence of species with similar pollination mechanisms, and therefore floral traits may not be good indicators of phylogenetic relationships in this group. The results of the phylogenetic analysis support this conclusion to some extent. There is no correlation between genetic (allozyme) and morphological variability in the populations and in the way this variability is distributed among conspecific populations. We describe a new subspecies of Pleurothallis ochreata based on differences in vegetative and chemical characters as well as geographic localization. Absence of differentiation in flora! characters, attraction of the same pollinator species, interfertility, and genetic similarity support the argument for subspecific rather than specific status. Key-words: Pleurothallis, Pleurothallis ochreata. subsp. cylindrifolia, Orchidaceae, morphometry, phylogeny, convergence, morphological variability, campo rupestre INTRODUCTION Delimitation of groups and their possible phylogenetic relationships in Orchidaceae has basically been done by using morphological floral characters. However, some decades ago, floral biologists drew attention to several convergence and radiation events that occurred in orchid floral characters due to pollination mechanisms, and consequently to the artificiality of classification in some groups (Dodson, 1962; van der Fiji and Dodson, 1966). Some of these cases have recently been confirmed by using macromolecular techniques (van den Berg et al., 2000; Whitten, Williams and Chase, 2000) and convergence and radiation in floral traits are probably widespread in this family (e.g. Johnson, Under and Steiner, 1998). More recently, the role of flora! and vegetative characters in orchid classification has been revised by several authors (e.g. Chase and Palmer, 1992). These cases of convergence due to similar specialized poll ¡nation mechanisms, generally refered to as pollination syndromes (van der Fiji and Dodson, 1966; Faegri and van der Fiji, 1979), have been criticized extensively (Herrera, 1996; Oilerton, 1996; Waser et al., 1996). On the other hand, Johnson and Steiner (2000) have argued in favour of the existence of syndromes in several groups. Using more objective morphometric multivariate methods, Sakai, Kato and Inoue (1999) have demonstrated the occurrence of convergence and radiation in floral traits and their correlation with pollination guilds in gingers. Borba et al. (2001a), studying five Pleurothallis species occurring in the Brazilian "campo rupestre" vegetation, found unexpectedly high genetic variability in several populations they surveyed and a low to moderately high differentiation among conspecific populations. These species are pollinated by flies belonging to the Chloropidae (P. johannensis Barb. Rodr. and P. fabiobarrosli Borba & Semir, pollinated by Tricimba sp.; P. adamantinensis Brade, pollinated by Hippelates sp.) and Phoridae (P. teres Lindl. and P. ochreata Lind!., pollinated by Megaselia spp.). Strong floral similarity in Pleurothallis species pollinated by the same fly species appears to occur (Borba and Semir, 2001). Based on their allozyme results, Borba etal. (2001a) have suggested that these floral similarities are due to convergence of species with similar pollination mechanisms, and therefore floral traits may not be good indicators of phylogenetic relationships in this group. In this study we present results of morphometric analyses using multivariate methods and phylogenetic analysis using DNA sequencing data from ITS carried out in the same populations of these five Pleurothallis species that were included in our previous studies on genetic variability (Borba et aL, 2001a), reproductive biology (Borba and Semir, 2001; Borba, Shepherd and Semir, 2001) and taxonomy (Borba etaL, 2000), Our aims were: i) to confirm the delimitation of these Pleurothallis species; ii) to verify the correlation between floral morphology and pollination guilds; iii) to outline the phylogenetic relationships among these species and then to test the convergence and radiation in floral traits hypotheses presented by Borba et aL (2001a); iv) to verify the existence of correlation between genetic and morphological variability and in the way this variability is distributed among conspecific populations. MATERIALS AND METHODS Morphometric analyses Plants of the five Pleurothallis species used for the morphometric analyses were collected in 21 natural populations at 16 localities in Minas Gerais (MG), Bahia (BA), and Pernambuco (PE) states, Southeast and Northeast Brazil: P. Johannensis (seven populations), P, teres (six populations), P. och reata (four populations), R fabiobarrosii (two populations), and R adamantinensis (two populations; Table 1; Fig. 1). Great care was taken to collect individuals from different clones, since these species can reproduce vegetatively. We sampled a total of 372 individuals of the five species. The individuals were maintained in a greenhouse at Universidade Estadual de Campinas, Campinas, São Paulo state (22°49’S, 47°06’W) for two to three years and we used leaves, stems and flowers developed in the greenhouse for measurements. In some exceptional cases we measured plant material collected directly in the field (Table 1). The climate of the areas where the individuals were collected is similar to that of Campinas, Cwb in Koeppen’s (1948) classification. Vouchers are deposited in the herbarium of the Universidade Estadual de Campinas (UEC; Table 1). We measured 35 continuous morphological characters, 26 flora! and 9 vegetative (Table 2; Fig. 2). Due to the minute size of the flowers, we dissected and drew them with the aid of a stereomicroscope equipped with a camera lucida and measurements were then made from the drawings for greater precision. Detailed descriptions and illustrations of floral and vegetative characters of these species may be found in Borba and Semir (2001) and Borba et al. (2000). We carried out Principal Component Analysis (PCA) with all characters, including ail individuals of the five species, and for each species separately as well. We also carried out cluster analyses for the populations using all characters, only floral characters, and only vegetative characters. For the population cluster analyses we used the Mahalanobis generalized distance calculated from the pooled residual covariances within groups matrix and UPGMA (Unweighted Pair-Group Method of Arithmetical Averages) as the clustering algorithm. We used a Multi-Response Permutation Procedure (MRPP) analysis to calculate the average within-group distance (delta) for all populations and the chance-corrected within-group agreement (A) among populations of every species. We then carried out an analysis of correlation between genetic variability and delta values, and between genetic differentiation among populations and A values for all populations of all five species pooled. We used observed mean heterozygosity (Ho) from allozyme data as a measure of genetic variability, and Fst (Wright, 1978) as a measure of genetic differentiation among populations (data from Borba eta/., 2001a, in which the same individuals of these populations were used). All the data were arcsin transformed before the calculation of the correlation coefficient and its significance was tested using Table B.17 in Zar (1999). The Mahalanobis generalized distance matrices (all variables, only flora! variables, and only vegetative variables) were compared to matrices of Nei’s (1978) genetic distance (from Borba et al., 2001a, data not shown) and geographic distance (see Appendix 1 of Borba et al., 2001a) of populations of P. johannensis and P. teres using the Mantel test, with the Monte Carlo option of PCOrd (1,000 randomizations). The procedure was not used for the other species, due to the low number of populations. The PCA, the MRPP analysis and the Mantel test were carried out using PCOrd 4.10 (McCune and Mefford, 1999) and the cluster analyses were done using the Statistica for Windows software package (StatSoft, 1995). Phylogenetic analysis Material from the five species (eight populations) used in the morphometric studies and another five samples of different lineages of Pleurothallidinae were selected (Table 3). DNA was extracted from fresh leaves using the protocols of Doyle and Doyle (1987) and purified through QIAquick silica columns (QIAGEN, Ltd.). ITS1,5.8S and ITS2 were amplified as a single piece using the primers 17SE and 26SE (Sun et al. 1994). PGR settings consisted of 4 min at 94°C (initial denaturation), 28 cycles of 1 min at 94°C (denaturation), 1 min at 50°C (annealling) and 3 min 72°C (extension), and 7 min at 72°C final extension. Resulting PCR products were purified using Concert (Gibco BRL) silica columns. Cycle sequencing was performed in both directions with the Big Dye Terminator Kit (Applied Biosystems) and run in an ABI 377 Automated Sequencer using manufacturers protocols. Eletropherograms were superimposed and edited with Sequencher 3.1.1. (Genecodes Inc., Ann Arbor, Michigan), and edited sequences were aligned by eye. Gaps in the matrix were coded as additional presence/absence characters and the gaps themselves treated as missing data. The dataset was analyzed with PAUP 4.0 (Swofford, 1998), using Fitch parsimony (Fitch, 1971; equally weighted, unordered character states) as optimality criterion and branch and bound search to find all the possible shortest trees. Support was assessed using 1000 replicates of character bootstrapping (Felsenstein, 1985). Trees were rooted with Octomeria gracilis as outgroup after this genus was indicated as sister to the remaining Pleurothallidinae (A. Pridgeon, comm. pers.). All sequences have been submitted to Genbank (accession numbers in Table 3). RESULTS Interspecific morphological variability In the ordination analysis (PCA), three groups were delimited on the first two axes (Fig. 3A). One of these groups is formed exclusively by all individuals of P. adamantinensis and is separated from the other groups mainly by the angles of floral parts and sepal length. The other groups are formed by the individuals of P. johannensis with P. fabiobarrosii and P. teres with R ochreata. These two groups are separated by the majority of the floral characters, almost all of them well represented on the first axis. These three groups are coincident with the three pollinator groups (Fig. 3A) found by Borba and Semir (2001a). The species within these two pairs (R johannensis~P. fabiobarrosii and R teres~P. ochreata) are separated on the third axis, which is formed mainly by vegetative characters (Fig. 3B). However, on the third axis there is some overlap of the individuals of R teres and R ochreata. This is due the similarity in leaf characters of the Grão Mogol population of R ochreata with R teres (Fig. 2D-E). The same relationships among the species found in the ordination may be observed in the cluster analyses, in the analyses including all characters and only floral characters there are five groups, each formed exclusively by all conspecific populations (Fig. 4A, B). Higher level groups are formed by the species pairs P. johannensis with R fabiobarrosii and R ochreata with R teres. In the analysis using only vegetative characters, the Grão Mogol population of R ochreata does not group with the other conspecific populations. This population clusters with the populations of P. teres (Fig. 4C). Higher level groups are formed by the species pairs R johannensis with R teres and R ochreata with R fabiobarrosii. Intraspecific morphological variability and genetic variability AH A values were statistically significant (all values of p<0.002), indicating that there is morphological structuring among conspecific populations in all species, The highest A value was observed in R ochreata (A=0.1255), due mainly to the differentiation in leaf characters of the Grão Mogol population (Fig. 2D, 4C, 5C). Intermediate values were observed in P. johannensis (A=0.0774), due mainly to the differentiation of the São João Del Rei population, which has individuals with more sulcate leaves (Fig. 5E-F), and in P. adamantinensis (A=0.0809), that has relatively high differentiation in leaf traits between the two populations (Fig, 4C, 5A). Relatively low A values were found in P, teres (A=0.0281) and R fabiobarrosii (A=0.0321), in spite of the apparent separation of the populations of the latter in the RCA (Fig. 5B, D). The correlation between species values of A and Fst was not significant (Fig. 6A; r=0.6486; df-3; p>0.05). A similar result was obtained for population values of delta and genetic variability (Ho; Fig. 6B; r=0.1010; df=19; p>0.05). The Mantel test shows no significant correlation between Mahalanobis generalized distance and geographic distance and between Mahalanobis generalized distance and Nei's genetic distance in P. johannensis (all values of p>0.15) and P. teres (all values of p>0.17). Phylogenetic analysis Branch and Bound search found 8 equally most parsimonious trees of 220 steps of length, Consistency Index (Cl) of 0.84 and Retention Index (Rl) of 0.7931. One of the trees is presented in Figure 7. A well-supported, closely related clade with all the five species of Pleurothallis was indicated. The samples from the three different populations of R ochreata were a sister clade to the remaning species with good bootstrap support (90 %). The clade with the remaining species had only 56 % of support and was internally unresolved except by the two samples of R teres, which were sister with 75 % of support. The relationships outside the Pleurothallis species group in this study were all well supported. DISCUSSION Species delimitation and phylogenetic relationships The results of the ordination and cluster analyses are in agreement with the species delimitation proposed by Borba et al. (2000) and also supported by allozyme (Borba et al., 2001 a), chemical (Borba et al., 2001c) and anatomical data (Scatena and Nunes, 1996). Borba et al. (2000) and Borba and Semir (2001) have pointed out the floral similarity of R johannensis with P. fabiobarrosii, and showed that these species are differentiated mainly in vegetative characters and minor lip traits. These affirmations are confirmed by the ordination analysis, in which these two species are separated mainly by vegetative characters. Conversely, the results of the duster analysis showed that these two species can also be recognized based only on their floral characters, especially lip width, lip isthmus length, lip calli and apex angles of flower parts. Based on the low genetic similarity between P. johannensis and P. fabiobarrosii (Nei’s, 1978, unbiased genetic identity = 0.565) and between P. ochreata and P. teres (genetic identity - 0.647), Borba et al. (2001a) suggested that floral similarity in these two pairs of species may be due to convergence in allopatric species with similar pollination mechanisms (Borba and Semir, 2001). Conversely, divergence by different pollination mechanisms may have occurred in the closely related P. johannensis and P. teres, species presenting high genetic similarity (0.774, rising to 0.80 if the highly differentiated Santa Maria Madalena population of P. teres is excluded from the analysis). Those authors also suggested that in this species group vegetative characters may be more informative in assessing phylogenetic relationships than floral ones. The species genetically most similar to P. ochreata is P. fabiobarrosii, the same occurring with P. teres in relation to P. johannensis. The occurrence of these same relationships in the cluster analysis using only vegetative characters and the strong association of the three pollination guilds with the three groups found both on the first three axes of the ordination (mainly formed by floral characters) and in the cluster analysis using only floral characters strengthen the hypotheses presented by Borba et al. (2001a). Recently ideas of phylogenetic relationships in Orchidaceae have been strongly challenged. Convergence and radiation in floral traits due to pollination mechanisms have been demonstrated in several orchid groups (e.g. Johnson et aL, 1998; van den Berg et aL, 2000), some of them suggested some decades ago (e.g. van der Fiji and Dodson, 1966, p. 94), and the role of floral and vegetative characters in assessing phylogenetic relationships has been discussed (e.g. Chase and Palmer, 1992). In spite of the recent debate about the existence (or non existence) of pollination syndromes and specialized pollination systems (see Herrera, 1996; Ollerton, 1996; Waser eta/., 1996; Johnson and Steiner, 2000), our data indicate the existence of specialization in pollination systems correlated with floral character sets which are to some extent predictable and largely compatible with the basic idea of poll ¡nation syndromes. Similar results have been found in other plant groups (e.g. Sakai et aL, 1999) and possibly are widespread in angiosperms. The phylogenetic analysis using ITS indicates that P. teres, P. fabiobarrosii, P. adamantinensis, and P. johannensis are closely related species, considering the number of substitutions among the species and comparing them to the number of substitutions between the two populations of P. teres and among the three populations of P. ochreata. These levels of variation we found are similar to that of species complexes in other Orchidaceae-Epidendroideae groups (Ryan et aL, 2000; van den Berg et aL, 2000). Taking into account the occurrence of only four substitutions between P. ochreata and the other four species, we may suggest that these are closely related groups. However, P. ochreata is not necessarily the closest species to the remainder since other species of this group have not been sampled. It is important to note that only P. ochreata has nodding inflorescences, the inflorescence of the remaining species being erect. Furthermore P. ochreata is the only species occurring in Northeast Brazil, while the rest are found exclusively in Southeast Brazil. The tow variation observed in ITS does not allow a conclusive test of the hypotheses of convergence in this group, but indicates that either convergence or radiation in floral traits must have occurred at least once. We suggest that it is more plausible that convergence must have occurred between P. ochreata and P. teres. Inclusion of other species belonging to this group in the analysis as well as inclusion of other genes is necessary to clarify these relationships. Differentiation in P. ochreata Pleurothallis ochreata is a species with a wide distribution in northeastern Brazil, especially in Bahia state, but it is also found in Pernambuco and Paraiba. The Grão Mogol population, in the north of Minas Gerais, is the only population known in southeastern Brazil, representing the southern extreme of distribution for this species (see Fig. 1). In spite of the fact that the "campos rupestres" of Grão Mogol belong to the same mountain chain of the core area P. ochreata. distribution (the Espinhaço chain), they are geographically isolated and high endemism has been found in this region (Giulietti and Pirani, 1988). Borba, Trigo and Semir (2001) studied the alkaloid profile of these Pleurothallis species and found that the Grão Mogol population of P. ochreata is differentiated from the remaining conspecific populations by an inversion of the relative abundance of 1-hydroxymethylpyrrolizidine isomers. However, Borba et al. (2001a) found no clear genetic differentiation in this population compared with the same populations sampled by Borba et al., (2001c) in their study with alkaloids. These populations also attract the same pollinator species (Borba and Semir, 2001) and are interfertile (Borba et al., 2001b). We have observed the occurrence of phenotypic plasticity in leaf traits in P. ochreata from Bahia and Pernambuco states: individuals growing in open areas usually have more fleshy and shorter leaves, but when cultivated in the greenhouse they produce larger and more flattened leaves, similar to those of individuals growing in shaded sited or as epiphytic individuals, and similar to the leaves of the holotype of the species. This characteristic led Pabst (1956) to give specific status to the rupicolous populations, as P. bahiensis Pabst, but this was subsequently synonymized by the same author (Pabst and Dungs, 1975). Plasticity was not observed in leaves of individuals of the Grão Mogol population (individuals of these populations have been cultivated in our greenhouse for nearly four years). Due to the differentiation found in both leaf and chemical (Borba et al., 2001c) characters, we propose subspecific status for the Grão Mogol population of P. ochreata: Pleurothallis ochreata subsp. cylindrifolia Borba and Semir subsp. nov. The absence of differentiation in floral characters, attraction of the same pollinator species (Borba and Semir, 2001), interfertility (Borba et al., 2001b), and genetic similarity, in which the Grao Mogol populations is nested within the other conspecific populations in both allozyme (Borba etal., 2001a) and ITS analyses, support the argument for subspecific rather than specific status for this population. This conclusion is reinforced by the geographical distribution, because P. ochreata subsp. cylindrifolia is restricted to the southern extreme of the species distribution. Furthermore, in spite of the difference in flowering time in the field of the Grao Mogo! population when compared with the other conspecific populations, all of them flower together when growing in the greenhouse (Borba and Semir, 2001). This differentiation in flowering time in the field may be due to differences in the rainy season at these localities (Borba and Semir, 2001). Even though it is relatively common for allozymic studies to confirm subspecies or geographic ''races" previously detected using either morphological or chemical data (e.g. Desrochers and Bohm, 1995), Hillis (1987) has pointed out that "historically distinct evolutionay lineages may not show any particular level of divergence at either morphological or molecular level". This point has also been stressed by Avise (1994). Intraspecific morphological variability and genetic variability Besides the absence of correlation between genetic and morphological variability in the populations, the absence of correlation in the way this variability is distributed among the conspecific populations is striking. For example, although P. ochreata showed both the highest A value (indicating high morphological differentiation) and Fst (indicating high genetic differentiation among populations; Borba et al., 2001a), these occur for different reasons: the high A is mainly due to the differentiation of leaf characters in the Grao Mogol population, and the high Fst is due to the differentiation in other populations (the highest values of genetic identity were found between the Grao Mogol population and the others; Borba et al., 2001 a). Pleurothallis johannensis presents a moderate A value, due to individuals with more deeply sulcate leaves in the São João Dei Rei populations, however this species presented a low Fst, with high similarity between this population and the remaining ones (Borba etal., 2001a). Similar results were obtained with R adamantinensis. Equally, although P. teres had low, but significant, values of A and Fst, no correlation between morphological and genetic similarity among the populations was observed (also in R johannensis), resulting in a different topology for the dendrograms (see Fig. 2 in Borba et al., 2001a). These results are not completely unexpected, since lack of congruence in partitioning of the variability among conspecific populations has been observed even when comparing different molecular markers (Avise, 1994). However, it is important to notice that in both morphological and genetic analyses, significant values of differentiation among conspecific populations were found. These plants grow on rock formations, as isolated islands of "campo rupestre" vegetation. Because of the discontinuity of the mountain ranges and outcrops where these species occur, they are distributed in disjunct populations. This characteristic has been suggested as the factor responsible for the great diversity and high endemism of these areas, among the highest in all Brazilian vegetation types (Joly, 1970; Giulietti and Pirani, 1988). Absence of correlation between morphological and genetic variability has frequently been found in diverse plant groups as well as in animals (Turner, 1974; Mitton, 1978; Handford, 1980; Jain et al., 1980; Gilles, 1984; Elisens, Boyd and Wolfe, 1992; Johannesson, Johannesson and Rolán-Alvarez, 1993; Avise, 1994; Andersson, 1995; Karakousis and Kyriakopoulou-Sklavounou, 1995). Giles (1984) has stressed that inferences about rates of evolution and variation must not be taken to apply to the whole organism, but apply only to particular set of characters. Recently, the importance of utilization of different molecular markers to determine evolutionary significant units for conservation has been discussed, and several studies have shown different methods resulting in different indicators (Avise, 1994; Newton et al., 1999). Our results confirm these statements and indicate that both morphological and genetic as well as geographical indicators should be taken in account for conservation management or germplasm collection in this group. Unfortunately, there are too few data available regarding these questions in Orchidaceae and any other plant groups of "campo rupestre" vegetation to test the extension of this conclusion for these areas, but these few studies support it (e.g. Jesus et al., 2001). Resultados similares foram também encontrados anteriormente em espécies de Bulbophyilum de campos rupestres (Borba, 1997; Borba & Semir, 1998; Borba et al., 1998: Silva et al., 1999). Obviamente, não é viável a realização de estudos tão abrangentes, abordando várias técnicas, para a solução de todos os problemas taxonómicos em plantas. Infelizmente, estes são possíveis apenas para a solução de alguns problemas pontuais, tais como o aqui apresentado. Desta forma, do ponto de vista da sistemática, a maior importância deste trabalho refere-se a criar modelos para melhor entendermos os processos e as causas da variação, e desta forma fornecer subsídios para que possamos observar de uma forma diferente da usual outros grupos de espécies, tanto de Orchidaceae como de campos rupestres em geral, para uma melhor delimitação de padrões (taxa) em taxonomía. Em nossos trabalhos prévios realizados com espécies de Bulbophyilum, foram utilizados apenas estudos de biologia reprodutiva e química de voíáteis florais, não tendo sido empregada uma abordagem multipopulacional (Borba, 1997; Borba & Semir, 1998, 1999; Borba et al., 1998, 1999; Silva et al., 1999), levando as nossas conclusões taxonómicas nestes trabalhos a serem um pouco mais limitadas. Apesar do estudo de genética de populações utilizando isozimas ter sido aquele que permitiu uma melhor abordagem taxonómica e uma melhor compreensão das relações interespecíficas, apenas a correlação de todas as técnicas empregadas levou a um quadro mais nítido destes aspectos. Como exemplo, podemos mencionar o fato da análise de isozimas ter apresentado a população de Grão Mogol de P. ochreata (P. ochreata subsp. cylindhfolia) inserida entre as outras populações conspecífícas, enquanto apenas os estudos de morfometria e fitoquímica indicaram a sua diferenciação. Vários resultados encontrados neste trabalho foram inesperados, tais como a elevada variabilidade genética nas populações, a relativamente baixa diferenciação entre populações conspecífícas, a elevada especificidade de polinizadores e auto- incompatibilidade. É difícil traçar uma comparação dos nossos resultados com os dos raros caos onde valores elevados de variabilidade genética foram observados em Orchidaceae, devido à praticamente ausência de estudos em espécies tropicais, além destes terem sido realizados com espécies filogenetícamente pouco relacionadas aos Pleurothallis (raros trabalhos foram desenvolvidos com espécies pertencentes à subfamilia Epidendroideae, na qual encontra-se a subtribo Pleurothallidinae). Nós sugerimos que a manutenção desta elevada variabilidade genética esteja relacionada, pelo menos parcialmente, à autoincompatibilidade encontrada nestas espécies, uma vez que o comportamento dos seus polinizadores favorece a autopolínizaçâo. Como autoincompatibilidade e elevada variabilidade genética são características incomuns em Orchidaceae, caso tivéssemos estudado apenas um destes aspectos poderíamos apenas realizar conclusões que seriam consideradas pouco prováveis por serem incomuns no grupo em questão. Por exemplo, caso observássemos apenas a autoincompatibilidade, poderíamos sugerir a ocorrência de elevada variabilidade genética. Da mesma forma, se tivéssemos realizado apenas um estudo mostrando a elevada variabilidade genética, uma sugestão plausível seria a ocorrência de algum mecanismo genético ou comportamental (do polinizador), ou ainda a presença de alguma barreira mecânica, que reduza as chances de formação de prole por endogamia nestas espécies. Estas conclusões certamente seriam recebidas como muito especulativas por se tratarem de argumentos que constituem eventos raramente ou nunca anteriormente observados em orquídeas. Mais além, a observância de apenas a biologia floral destas espécies, levaria à sugestão de um quadro de baixa variabilidade genética nas populações e elevada diferenciação entre populações devido ao comportamento do polinizador, assim como previamente hipotetizado por nós, e frequentemente especulado para orquídeas com características ecológicas similares. Acreditamos que a demonstração conjunta por nós realizada da ocorrência destes eventos permitirá uma maior previsibilidade destes em Orchidaceae. A especificidade observada na polinização das espécies está provavelmente sendo operada através de compostos voláteis florais, assim como encontrado em Bulbophyllum (Borba & Semir, 1998; Silva et al., 1999). Nestes trabalhos, nós sugerimos a existência de uma relação entre moscas da família Mílichiidae e espécies de Bulbophyllum neotropicais. Estas especies de Bulbophyllum apresentam uma abundância de compostos possuindo anéis pirânicos e furânicos, e ausência de compostos nitrogenados, características que têm sido observadas para várias outras espécies do gênero (Christiano F. Verola et al., dados não publicados). Diferentemente do que ocorre em Bulbophyllum, estudos a respeito dos voláteis florais destas espécies de Pleurothallis indicam a ausência de piranos e furanos e a presença de compostos nitrogenados, inclusive derivados do alcalóide 1-hidróxi-metilpirrolizidína, presente em flores e folhas destas espécies (Eduardo L. Borba e José R. Trigo, dados não publicados). Alcalóides pirrolizidínicos são metabólitos secundários de plantas normalmente associados a defesa contra herbívoros, e são sequestrados por alguns grupos de insetos, particularmente Lepidoptera, sendo utilizados por estes como defesa contra predação (Trigo, 2000). Foi observado que espécies de Chloropidae também são atraídos e se alimentam em iscas contendo alcalóides pirrolizidínicos (Boppré & Pitkin, 1988; José R. trigo, comunicação pessoal), e néctar de espécies miiófilas tipicamente apresentam compostos nitrogenados como um de seus constituintes (Proctor et al., 1996). Estudos de caracterização química de voláteis florais e néctar, inclusive com a utilização de bioensaios, podem ajudar a esclarecer as relações destas espécies de moscas com seus visitantes florais e a natureza da especificidade observada, assim como as relações das espécies de Pleurothallis e Bulbophyllum com as diferentes famílias de Díptera. Estes estudos encontram-se no momento em desenvolvimento por nosso grupo. Ausência de correlação entre variabilidade genética e morfológica e na forma como esta encontra-se distribuída em populações conspecíficas não era completamente inesperada por nós, e tem sido observada em diversos grupos de organismos (Gilíes, 1984; Avise, 1994). Porém, é importante notar que tanto a variabilidade genética quanto morfológica, assim como a estruturação destas, apresentaram valores expressivos em todas as populações e espécies. A importância da utilização de diferentes marcadores genéticos e morfológicos na determinação de unidades para conservação in situ e ex situ tem sido amplamente discutida, e vários estudos tem demonstrado que diferentes técnicas podem levar a conclusões divergentes (Avise, 1994; Newton et al., 1999). Os nossos resultados indicam que marcadores morfológicos e marcadores genéticos, assim como indicadores geográficos, produzem informações complementares neste grupo de espécies e ambos devem ser levados em consideração para elaboração de programas com finalidade de conservação e de manejo. Apesar de estudos abordando estes aspectos em Orchidaceae ou quaisquer outros grupos de plantas de campos rupestres serem praticamente ausentes, existem indícios que estas conclusões possam ser expandidas de uma maneira geral para espécies vegetais ocorrendo nestes ambientes (Jesus et aL, 2001). Estudos empregando diferentes marcadores moleculares podem fornecer importante informação adicional às apresentadas neste trabalho. Devido à baixa variação observada na sequências de ITS entre as espécies e à. limitação de isozimas como informativa sobre relações fílogenéticas, estudos envolvendo microsatélites podem ser os mais indicados para a confirmação definitiva das hipóteses apresentadas sobre relações fílogenéticas neste grupo, além da possibilidade de fornecer informações sobre rotas de migração de algumas espécies, resultados que seriam particularmente interessantes para P. teres e P. ochreata. Estamos estudando a utilização desta técnica em projetos futuros, envolvendo tanto este quanto outros grupos de orquídeas. Existem indícios que populações disjuntas de P. teres, representadas em ambientes diferentes dos campos rupestres, possam existir em outras localidades (recebemos material adicional de P. teres coletado no Espírito Santo após a conclusão dos nossos trabalhos; Espírito Santo: Santa Teresa, Pedra da Onça, L. Apêndice 6 - Chave para identificação dos seis taxa de Pleurothallis de folhas aproximadamente cilíndricas ou carnosas ocorrentes em campos rupestres reconhecidos neste trabalho. 1- Inflorescencias eretas. 2~ Folhas cilíndricas sulcadas, com diâmetro lateral semelhante ao diâmetro dorsiventral; caules secundários pouco diferenciados e com diâmetro semelhante ao diâmetro das folhas, formando um contínuo com estas. 3- Inflorescências aproximadamente o dobro do comprimento das folhas mais o caule secundário; caule secundário do mesmo comprimento ou maiores do que as folhas; labelo indistintamente trilobado; flores 9-13mm comp. Cadeia do Espinhaço na região centro-norte e norte de Minas Gerais (Grão Mogol e Diamantina)................. P, adamantínensis Brade. 3’- Inflorescencias menores ou pouco maiores do que o comprimento das folhas mais o caule secundário; caule secundário muito menores do que as folhas; labelo nitidamente trilobado; flores até 8mm comp. 4- Pétalas 2-3mm comp.; labelo 2-3,5mm comp.; coluna 2-2,5mm comp.; flores emitindo odor de queijo rançoso. Cadeia do Espinhaço na região centro e centro-norte de Minas Gerais e em afloramentos de granito no Rio de Janeiro e Espírito Santo .........P. teres Lindl. 4’- Pétalas 3,5-5mm comp.; labelo 4-6mm comp.; coluna 3-4,5mm comp.; flores emitindo odor de peixe.
